wikipedia_page.main: Lieutenant General Sir John Macdonald GCB (before 1795 – 28 March 1850) was Adjutant-General to the Forces.

response: John Macdonald or MacDonald may refer to:
*John Macdonald Kinneir (1782-1830), Scottish army officer of the East India Company, envoy to Persia
*John Macdonald, Lord Kingsburgh (1836–1919), Scottish politician and later a judge
*John Macdonald (Canadian politician) (1824–1890), member of parliament and later senator
*John Macdonald (British Army officer) (bef. 1795–1850), Adjutant-General to the Forces
*John Macdonald (Australian Army officer) (1919–1996), University of New South Wales Regiment
*John Macdonald (sportsman) (1861–1938), represented Scotland at both cricket and football
*John Macdonald (footballer, born 1886) (1886–1960), Scottish footballer for Raith Rovers, Rangers, Liverpool, Newcastle United
*John Macdonald (Canadian football) (born 1978), Canadian football defensive linemen
*John Macdonald (psychiatrist) (1920–2007), New Zealand forensic psychiatrist who coined the MacDonald triad of sociopathy

Born in the Isle of Skye in one of the oldest families living on the island, his father was Rev. Donald Martin and his mother was the daughter of Norman Macdonald and sister of Lieut-Gn. Sir John Macdonald. Martin was educated at St George's and Windmill Street School. He became a C.C.S. in 1811 and entered the Bengal Medical Service on 5 September 1817. He obtained commission of assistant-surgeon through the interest of his uncle, Sir John MacDonald, the Adjutant-General to the Forces.Biographical sketch in the London Lancet

He was the third son of General Frederick William Buller of Pelynt and Lanreath in Cornwall, who had himself served with distinction in the 57th Foot in the Netherlands and the West Indies. George was gazetted a second lieutenant in the Rifle Brigade on 2 March 1820. The first twenty-five years of his career in the army were spent in a time of peace, and his marriage with Henrietta, daughter of General Sir John Macdonald, Adjutant-General to the Forces, helped his rapid promotion. He became lieutenant in March 1825; captain, in August 1828; major, in December 1830; lieutenant-colonel in August 1835; and colonel in November 1841.
